message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypertension and presence of bruits near the umbilicus suggest a possible renal artery stenosis. The best next step in management would be a renal ultrasound with Doppler to evaluate for this possibility before increasing the dose of current medications or switching to a different medication. A CT abdomen/pelvis would be useful if a structural abnormality or mass was suspected. Lisinopril may not be effective if the patient has renal artery stenosis and increasing the dose of current medications would not be recommended without further evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bruits bilaterally on the abdomen suggest the presence of renal artery stenosis, which can cause resistant hypertension. A renal ultrasound with Doppler can confirm the diagnosis and determine if surgical intervention is needed. CT abdomen/pelvis and increasing the dose of current blood pressure medications are not helpful in this situation. Lisinopril is an option for treatment of hypertension, but it should not be initiated without further evaluation for renal artery stenosis in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of smoking, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and presence of bruits suggest the possibility of renal artery stenosis. Renal ultrasound with Doppler is the best next step to evaluate for this possibility. Increasing the dose of current blood pressure medications or adding lisinopril may not be effective if renal artery stenosis is present. CT abdomen/pelvis may be considered if other options are inconclusive, but it is not the best initial step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest renal artery stenosis, which is a common cause of secondary hypertension in older individuals. Renal ultrasound with Doppler can help diagnose this condition and guide treatment. CT abdomen/pelvis can also show the renal arteries, but it is not as sensitive as renal ultrasound with Doppler. Increasing the dose of current blood pressure medications or starting a new medication without addressing the underlying cause would not be a good approach. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which may have some benefit in this case, but addressing the underlying cause should be the priority.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypertension and bilateral bruits suggest renal artery stenosis. A renal ultrasound with Doppler can confirm this diagnosis and guide the appropriate treatment. CT abdomen/pelvis is not recommended as a first-line investigation for renal artery stenosis. Increasing the dose of current blood pressure medications or starting a new medication may not be effective until the underlying cause of hypertension is identified and addressed. Lisinopril is an anti-hypertensive medication but may not be the best choice in this particular case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bruits bilaterally near the umbilicus indicates renal artery stenosis as the likely cause of hypertension. Renal ultrasound with Doppler is the best next step in management to confirm the diagnosis. Increasing the dose of current blood pressure medications may not work well if the underlying cause of hypertension is not addressed. CT abdomen/pelvis and lisinopril are not the recommended initial steps in management of renal artery stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's risk factors for renal artery stenosis, such as age, smoking history, and diabetes type II, along with the presence of bruits near the umbilicus, suggest that a renal ultrasound with Doppler should be the next step in management to assess for renal artery stenosis. Increasing the dose of current medications or adding a new medication may not be effective if the underlying cause is renal artery stenosis. CT abdomen/pelvis is not the first-line option for evaluating renal artery stenosis. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor often used for hypertension, but it is not the best next step in management for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bruits near the umbilicus suggest renal artery stenosis, and it is likely that the patient’s hypertension is caused by this. Renal ultrasound with Doppler can confirm the diagnosis and guide further management. The other options are not necessary at this point and may not address the underlying issue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s physical exam suggests renal artery stenosis, which can cause secondary hypertension. A renal ultrasound with Doppler can confirm this diagnosis and is the best next step in management. Increasing the dose of current medications or starting a new one like Lisinopril may not address the underlying cause of the hypertension. CT abdomen/pelvis can also provide information, but it is not the best first step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's hypertension, history of smoking and diabetes, and presence of bruits suggest renovascular disease. The most appropriate next step in management would be renal ultrasound with Doppler to evaluate for renal artery stenosis. CT abdomen/pelvis may also be helpful in evaluating the renal arteries, but renal ultrasound with Doppler is less invasive and less expensive. Increasing the dose of current blood pressure medications may not be effective if the underlying cause is renovascular disease. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which may be appropriate for hypertension management, but the underlying cause needs to be identified first.
